Award.AwardTitle: Achieving Sub-PPM Mass Accuracy for MALDI-FTICR Mass Spectrometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program, Prof. Jonathan Amster and his group at the University of Georgia will design, construct, and test new analyzer cells for Fourier transform mass spectrometry. These cells will substantially improve the performance of Fourier transform mass spectrometry compared to the current state-of-the-art. The Amster group will also use computer simulations of the motion of large populations of ions to develop a deeper understanding of the cell design features and experimental parameters on instrument performance. The overall goal of these efforts is to achieve parts-per-billion accuracy for mass measurement of ions formed by matrix assisted laser desorption mass spectrometry. This will provide an improvement of several orders of magnitude in mass accuracy relative to that which can currently be achieved in these experiments.

Mass is one of the most fundamental properties of matter, and the capability to measure it accurately impacts many areas of science. Laser desorption mass spectrometry is used for chemical imaging measurements, so the proposed developments may lead to more specific identification of molecules and their spatial distribution in samples such as tissues. Graduate and undergraduate students involved in this project will benefit from a multidisciplinary education, and will learn to effectively communicate their results by speaking at conferences and by writing papers for publication in peer-reviewed journals. Professor Amster regularly teaches a short-course on Fourier transform mass spectrometry, and the results of this project will supplement the course material. The fundamental knowledge gained from this project will also be disseminated in a web-based tutorial on the subject.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mass of a molecule is one its most fundamental properties, and its measurement is required for many research projects in chemistry, biology, and physics. Mass spectrometers are the prinicipal type of instrument that can make this measurement. The most precise and accurate of these instruments is the Fourier transform ion cyclotron resonance mass spectrometer (FTICR-MS). This research project used a computer modeling approach to develop a fundamental understanding of the inner workings of the FTICR-MS instrument, and provided data for technological advances that will provide even better accuracy in mass measurement. The validity of the computer modeling was tested by comparing simulation results to experimental findings. In this manner, we developed a much deeper understanding of the performance of the FTICR-MS instrument than could be obtained by either experiments or simulations alone. These findings will benefit researchers not only in the physical sciences, but also in biology and the biomedical sciences. We anticipate an immediate impact in the new and growing field of mass spectrometry imaging, by providing the means to obtain highly accurate mass measurements that are stable to the challenging conditions required to produce an image with microscopic detail. This goals of this project were advanced through collaborations with an international group of computer scientists and experimentalists, and provided a valuable training experience for the graduate students that participated in this project. Students traveled abroad to work in one collaborator's laboratory in the Netherllands, exposing them to the scientific culture on a world-wide stage. The students were able to report their findings in conferences with a national scope, also an invaluable training experience.
